nodes.bodyText: It's not clamping, the change is added to the start, rather than being between start and end. I'm not sure how delta is any clearer than change.
nodes.diffHunk:

 	METHOD method_15347 approximatelyEquals (FF)Z
 		ARG 0 a
 		ARG 1 b

@@ -28,6 +28,11 @@ CLASS net/minecraft/class_3532 net/minecraft/util/math/MathHelper
 	METHOD method_15347 approximatelyEquals (FF)Z
 		ARG 0 a
 		ARG 1 b
+	METHOD method_15348 capChange (FFF)F

nodes.bodyText:
You correctly point out that there are two ways of looking at what this method does.

You could look at it like a clamp, where end clamped between start - abs(maxChange) and start + abs(maxChange). This is how the method is actually implemented.
You could look at it as changing a variable from start to end, but only being able to change it by up to a certain amount (maxChange).

Although these are mathematically equivalent, I believe the second one is much more intuitive to think about, and also fits better with how the method is actually used.

nodes.bodyText: maybe "provoked"?
Not part of your PR, but can you rename this method to canClimb please?
I think that would conflict with an existing method (Entity#canClimb)
It could still do with a rename. i.e. what's the difference between spider canClimb and entity canClimb
Entity one is for climbing ladders and vines, while the spider one is for climbing on any block
Turns out this is actually for when the spider is climbing a wall, rather than when it can climb a wall.

nodes.bodyText: It's like capChange except it calls subtractAngles to subtract the angle. Using capChange on angles instead of this method (or capAngularChange) may produce uncapped or otherwise incorrect results in some cases.
